FacilityName: South County Regional Water Treatment Plant

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
It is the policy of Collier County to maintain compliance, provide a reliable source of drinking water to our customers, take care of customers concerns and to ensure the safety of our team members.  In order to accomplish these goals the Collier County team works to ensure that all preventative and mitigation steps are taken so that customers and residents surrounding the South Regional Water Treatment Plant are safe.  Collier County also has a strong relationship with the first response agencies and has them conduct regular exercises on site to ensure that should there ever be an event that they are familiar with our facility.

Regulated Substances
The primary activity at the South Regional Water Treatment Plant is to treat raw water to meet all potable drinking water standards.  Chlorine is the only 40 CFR 68 regulated substance at the facility.  Chlorine is used primarily as a disinfectant.  The maximum amount of chlorine at the facility at a time is 30 tons.

Accidential Release Prevention Program
Collier County is in compliance with 40 CFR 68.  The County has conducted a comprehensive review of the chlorine system as well as admnistrative, technical, operating and maintenance procedures.  The County has both passive mitigation, an enclosed building; and active mitigation, an emergency scrubber to minimize the consequences of an accidential release.  

Emergency Response Plan
The SCRWTP has an emergency response program that is coordinated with the Collier County Comprehensive Emergency Emergency Response Plan (ERP) that has been prepared in accordance with all local, state, and federal regulations.

Process Hazard Analysis Updates
In the 1999 submittal, there were a number of items that still needed to be accomplished that were identified in the Process Hazard Analysis.  The following is the items that were listed and the status on fulfilling the recommendations:

olliding with the building.  A sign indicating 10 mph speed limit should be posted along the roadway. All construction contract documents should require the contractor to maintain the roadway in suitable condition for safe use of chemical truck vehicles.  Status:  Completed.
B. The chlorine piping system should be modified to isolate the pressure guage from the header to prevent a potential leak at the header pressure guage.  Status: Completed.
C. Request Standard Operating Procedures and certifications that chlorine meets AWWA specifications from chlorine supplier. Status:  Completed.
D. Spare injectors and check valves should be purchased and kept on site for backup in case of a failure.  Status: Completed.
E. Emergency evacuation plan should be revised to include a second egress route as well as a reassembly area for personnel to meet.  A site coordinator should be assigned to every shift.  Status: Completed - on-going updates as shift assignments are alternated.
F. Due to the chemical nature of chlorine any work performed in the chlorine areas that involves heat or sparks should be closely monitored. Hot work permit process should be implemeneted.  Status: Completed.
G. A program for respirator maintenance and training that provides for purchase of spare parts and cartridge replacement should be implemented.  Status:  Completed set-up of program - on-going maintenance activities.
H. The monorail used to move chlorine containers has a potential of sticking in place.  The monorail should be lubricated.  Status: Completed.
I. Chlorine containers must be rotated in the trunnions to properly align the valves prior to connection. Purchase a "f" wrench for this use.  Status: Completed.
